caption: Mexican drug kingpin Joaquin "El Chapo" Guzman donated millions of dollars to Clinton Foundation.

result.explanation: The image shows Joaquin "El Chapo" Guzman, a Mexican drug kingpin.  The caption mentions a donation to the Clinton Foundation, which is not depicted in the image.  The image only shows the person, his ethnicity, and the context of his arrest.  There is no visual evidence supporting the claim about the Clinton Foundation donation.

candidates.title: Did El Chapo Donate Millions to Clinton Foundation?
candidates.content:
Claim:
Mexican drug kingpin Joaqun "El Chapo" Guzmn donated millions of dollars to Clinton Foundation.
On 9 January 2017, the web site Times.com.mx published an article reporting that Mexican Drug kingpin Joaqun "El Chapo" Guzmn had donated millions of dollars to the Clinton Foundation, claiming that WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange had broken the news while speaking at a "conference over the weekend":
Julian Assange launched an attack on the integrity of the Clinton Foundation with the latest intelligence report that says the organization had ties with Mexican drug cartel leader, Joaqun El Chapo Guzmn.
Guzman, widely known as El Chapo, has an estimated net worth of $2 billion USD. He is currently incarcerated in a high-security Mexican prison and is in the process of being extradited to the United States.
This article was published on 9 January 2017, and while the author claimed that Assange made the comment at a "conference" over the weekend (referring to the 7th and 8th of January), the included photograph was actually taken in February 2016, when the WikiLeaks founder appeared via a video stream for a news conference in which he discussed his possible extradition to Sweden over a sexual assault charge, not improper donations from El Chapo to the Clinton Foundation.
As well, Times.com.mx suggested that Assange made his comment in a room full of reporters, yet no legitimate news reports or video clips have surfaced confirming that Assange made any such statment. Furthermore, Times.com.mx did not provide any links to back up their sources or any specific details (such as the time and place of this "conference") which could give their report credibility.
While Times.com.mx does not carry a readily available disclaimer labeling its contents as fiction, this story of theirs is clearly just more fake news.
candidates.description: Reports that Mexican drug kingpin "El Chapo" donated millions to Hillary Clinton's campaign are fake news.

result.explanation: The provided text from Snopes explicitly debunks the claim that El Chapo donated millions to the Clinton Foundation.  Snopes details how the original claim originated from a dubious source (Times.com.mx) and lacks supporting evidence.  The Snopes article directly refutes the news caption's assertion.
result.supporting_points: Reports that Mexican drug kingpin "El Chapo" donated millions to Hillary Clinton's campaign are fake news.

final_result.explanation: The image shows Joaquin "El Chapo" Guzman, a Mexican drug lord, during his arrest. The caption claims that he donated millions of dollars to the Clinton Foundation.  Internal validation reveals no visual evidence in the image to support the claim of a donation to the Clinton Foundation; the image only depicts the arrest. The internal check gives a confidence score of 10 and a verdict of False because the image provides no information about any financial transactions. External validation, using Snopes, confirms that the claim is false. Snopes' detailed investigation shows the claim originated from a dubious source and lacks supporting evidence.  Snopes explicitly refutes the news caption's assertion, providing a confidence score of 10 and a verdict of False.  The strong agreement between the internal and external checks, both with high confidence scores, definitively indicates that the caption is out of context. There's no visual tampering or miscontextualization; the image accurately depicts the arrest of El Chapo, but this visual information is unrelated to the caption's claim.  There is no visual evidence supporting the claim about donations.The lack of evidence visually and external fact-checking sites, along with highly confident (10/10) scores from both checks, strongly support the conclusion that the caption is completely out of context.  The assertion lacks any visual support and is factually incorrect according to a reputable fact-checking source.
final_result.validation_summary: Both internal and external validation methods strongly indicate that the caption is out of context.  The image shows El Chapo's arrest, which is unrelated to the claim about donations to the Clinton Foundation.  External fact-checking definitively refutes the claim.
